lessons.title: Introduction to Circuits
lessons.overview: Learn the fundamentals of electrical circuits, voltage, current, and resistance.

blocks.heading: What is a Circuit?
blocks.content: A circuit is a closed path that allows electricity to flow from a power source, through components, and back to the source. A simple circuit needs a power source (battery), conductors (wires), and a load (light bulb, motor, etc.).

blocks.heading: Ohm's Law
blocks.content: Ohm's Law describes the relationship between voltage (V), current (I), and resistance (R): V = IR. Voltage is measured in Volts, current in Amperes, and resistance in Ohms (Ω). If voltage increases, current increases proportionally.

blocks.heading: Series vs Parallel Circuits
blocks.content: In series circuits, current flows through one path. If one component fails, the entire circuit breaks. In parallel circuits, current has multiple paths. If one path breaks, others continue working. Home wiring uses parallel circuits.

quiz.question: A circuit has 12V and 3Ω resistance. What is the current?

lessons.title: Simple Machines and Mechanical Advantage
lessons.overview: Discover how simple machines make work easier by trading force for distance.

blocks.heading: The Six Simple Machines
blocks.content: The six classical simple machines are: lever, wheel and axle, pulley, inclined plane, wedge, and screw. All complex machines are combinations of these basic types. They make work easier by changing the direction or magnitude of force.

blocks.heading: Mechanical Advantage
blocks.content: Mechanical advantage (MA) is the ratio of output force to input force. MA = Output Force / Input Force. A lever with MA = 3 means you can lift 300N with only 100N of force. However, you must move your end 3 times farther.

blocks.heading: Efficiency
blocks.content: No machine is 100% efficient due to friction and other energy losses. Efficiency = (Useful Work Out / Total Work In) × 100%. A 75% efficient machine converts 75% of input energy to useful work, losing 25% to heat and friction.

quiz.question: A lever allows you to lift 600N with 200N of force. What is its mechanical advantage?

lessons.title: Structures and Forces
lessons.overview: Understand how engineers design structures to withstand different types of forces.

blocks.heading: Types of Forces on Structures
blocks.content: Structures experience tension (pulling), compression (pushing), shear (sliding), torsion (twisting), and bending forces. Cables experience tension, columns experience compression, and beams experience both.

blocks.heading: Strength of Shapes
blocks.content: Triangles are the strongest shape because they can't be deformed without changing the length of sides. This is why bridges and towers use triangular trusses. Arches distribute weight effectively by converting vertical forces to compression.

blocks.heading: Center of Gravity
blocks.content: The center of gravity is the point where all weight appears to act. Objects with low centers of gravity are more stable. Wide bases and low centers of gravity prevent tipping. This principle is crucial in vehicle and building design.

quiz.question: What is the strongest geometric shape for building structures?
